13% of participants continued to shed SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the feces at 4 months after diagnosis & 4% shed at 7 months. GI symptoms are associated with fecal shedding of RNA.

Compared with healthy controls, the capillary density of Long COVID patients was decreased by 41%. Data strongly suggest that COVID leaves persistent capillary rarefication even 18 months after infection.

SARS-CoV-2 spike antigen in a majority of post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 infection patients up to 12 months post-diagnosis (n = 63), suggesting the presence of an active persistent SARS-CoV-2 viral reservoir.

Presence of residual virus within the appendix and breast tissue of 2 patients who exhibited LC symptoms, 175 to 462 days upon positive diagnosis: positive staining for viral nucleocapsid protein (NP) in the appendix, and tumour-adjacent region of the breast, but not within the tumour via multiplex immunohistochemistry. Notably, with RNAscope, both positive-sense and negative-sense (replicative intermediate) viral RNA were detected.

Long COVID is very common. Systematic review and meta-analysis including 196 studies and 120,970 participants (mean age: 52.3 years; 48.8% females) showed that long COVID may affect more than half of the patients, after a median of six months from the diagnosis.
In a large study with thousands of participants, vaccination did NOT reduce long COVID risks.

Small percentage of co-infections in SARS-CoV-2 positive patients who died with typical COVID-19 symptoms strongly suggests that the majority of SARS-CoV-2 infected patients died from and not with the virus.
Even in patients with mild COVID-19 who did not require supplemental oxygen or ventilatory support, sequelae were reported by 49.5% of them.

Data from 968 French adult patients indicate that about 10% of people infected by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 experience post COVID-19 disease. 85% of people with symptoms 2 months post COVID still have symptoms after 1 year.

According to a meta-analysis of 81 studies 32% of patients have fatigue at 12 weeks, 31% at 6+ months, 22% have cognitive impairment at 12 weeks, 21% at 6+ months.
Meta analysis shows that 45% of post COVID patients have pulmonary fibrosis. Affected tend to be older and have suffered worse COVID course.

Our data support the model in which SARS-CoV-2 reaches the brain, infects astrocytes, and consequently, leads to neuronal death or dysfunction. These deregulated processes could contribute to the structural and functional alterations seen in the brains of COVID-19 patients.

Cognitive deficits from long COVID are similar to aging the brain 20 years.

üêÅ Neuroinvasion and anosmia are independent phenomena upon infection with SARS-CoV-2 and its variants. All strains and variants tested (Wuhan, Gamma, Delta, Omicron/BA.1, and the ORF7ab‚Äêdeleted mutant) showed ability to infect (or at least presence of virus) in the olfactory bulbs. Viral titers and RNA loads in olfactory bulbs were above detection for all groups. Evidence supports the olfactory pathway (sensory neurons in nose ‚Üí olfactory epithelium ‚Üí olfactory bulb neurons) as a route for brain invasion. No strong evidence was found for infection spreading via blood vessels or widespread brain infection beyond olfactory bulbs in this model. Retrograde and anterograde movement along axons was observed in in vitro neuron-epithelial systems. The original Wuhan strain caused the most severe clinical signs (e.g. weight loss), followed by Gamma, then Delta, and Omicron/BA.1 caused the mildest signs. Wuhan strain: high rate of full anosmia (complete loss) in many animals. Gamma: fewer full anosmia, but many animals had impaired smell. Delta & Omicron/BA.1: no detectable olfactory deficits in the behavioral test used ‚Äì they did not lose smell. Removing ORF7ab from the Wuhan strain reduced incidence of anosmia: only ~25% of animals with ORF7-deleted virus showed anosmia vs ~62.5% with wild-type Wuhan. However, deletion of ORF7ab did not reduce neuroinvasion: virus still reached olfactory bulbs, etc.
Persistent post-COVID-19 smell loss is associated with inflammatory infiltration and altered olfactory epithelial gene expression.
Loss of smell & taste intensified long after people had Covid.
Cross-reactive immunity against the SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant is low in pediatric patients with prior COVID-19 or MIS-C

Tallying the natural history of post-vaccine breakthrough infections (BTI) in 33,000 people with over 13 million controls gives a vaccination protection from long covid of around 15%, much less than many other studies (reporting around 50%).
A higher ICU admission rate was observed in reinfection compared to first infection. Complete recovery rate after reinfection stood at 97.9%.

Asymptomatic and mild COVID-19 significantly remodels the maternal-fetal interface. Single-cell RNA sequencing reveals immunological rewiring at the maternal-fetal interface following asymptomatic/mild SARS-CoV-2 infection.
Household transmission is high, and children are a major driver.

Wearing a mask is 1,000 times more important than wiping surfaces. The estimated probability of infection was about 1 per 100 exposures to SARS-CoV-2-laden aerosols through inhalation and as high as 1 per 100,000 exposures from contacting contaminated surfaces in simulated scenarios.
Vaccination and masking by teachers and students mitigates transmission in schools.
Aerosol particle escape from surgical masks due to imperfect sealing.
Overview of filtration efficiency through masks.

Comparison of FDA and NIOSH facemask and respirator filtration test methods. Particulate filtration efficiency (PFE), bacterial filtration efficiency (BFE) and viral filtration efficiency (VFE) are FDA methods. The NaCl aerosol test is an NIOSH method. NaCl method was significantly (p < 0.05) more strict.
A bearded man is a more dangerous carrier than a clean-shaven man...one working with infectious microorganisms should wash his beard.
Rapid initiation of twice-daily nasal saline irrigation reduces severity in high-risk COVID+ outpatients.

Of 272 (20%) healthcare workers who seroconverted, the presence of HLA-DRB1*13:02 was associated with a 6¬∑7-fold increased risk of case definition symptomatic COVID-19.
In terms of immune responsiveness, HLA-DRB1*15:02 was associated with lower nucleocapsid T-cell responses.

Larger gray matter volumes in neuropsychiatric long COVID.
Significantly enlarged gray matter volume in long COVID patients was present in several clusters when compared to controls.

Each SARS-CoV-2 reinfection causes more severe disease. Compared to people who did not get reinfection, those with reinfection had 2 fold increased risk of death, 3 fold increased risk of hospitalization, 3 fold increased risk of heart problems and 3 fold increased risk of blood clotting.
When compared to RT-qPCR, the sensitivity of Architect and Alinity SARS-CoV2 assays was 69.5% and 64.8%, respectively.
BQ.1.1 escapes Evusheld and bebtelovimab, making all clinically available antibody drugs ineffective. BQ.1.1 and BA.2.75.2 both displayed sufficient hACE2 binding capability.

SARS-CoV-2-specific T cell response magnitude is significantly greater in those who remain protected versus those who become infected (P<1e-4); relatively low magnitude T cell response results in a 43.2% risk of infection, whereas high magnitude reduces this risk to 5.4%.

Single-cell multiomics revealed the dynamics of antigen presentation, immune response and T cell activation in the COVID-19 positive and recovered individuals. Covid recovered are missing a subset of Naive T cells in general that are specific to other viruses.
No presence of the susceptible (HLA-DRB1*04) while protective allele for GCA (HLA-DRB1*15) allele was detected in two patients.
Defective antifungal immunity in patients with COVID-19
Evidence of viral presence in the lung up to 359 days after the acute phase of disease, including in patients with negative nasopharyngeal swab tests.
Some tests are more prone to seroreversion than others. Seroreversion, the opposite of seroconversion, is where antibody levels decrease in number over time.

National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease found that autopsies of people who died from COVID19 show that the virus spread throughout the body and remained in tissue for months. The study broadened scientists‚Äô perspectives on where SARS-CoV-2 could cause infection and persist, including the brain.

Tonsils and adenoids are important sites of SARS-CoV-2 infection in asymptomatic children. Flow cytometry revealed that CD123+ dendritic cells were the most frequently infected cell type (10.57%)  followed by CD14+ monocytes (6.32%), CD4+ T lymphocytes (1.75%), CD20+ B lymphocytes (1.67%), and in less extent CD8+ T lymphocytes cells (1.36%).

A cohort of #covid19 survivors (~ 58% fully vaccinated with mRNA post infection) show up for bariatric surgery. 1/3 had #SARSCOV2 proteins in their stomachs/gallbladders a median of 9+ months after covid19 irrespective of vax.

Markedly elevated levels of full-length spike protein, unbound by antibodies, were detected in the plasma of individuals with post-vaccine myocarditis, whereas no free spike was detected in asymptomatic vaccinated control subjects.
The role of NSP6 in the biogenesis of the SARS-CoV-2 replication organelle.
SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid exhibits significant homology with MS-associated proteins across both 9mer and 15mer peptide groups.

Presence of residual virus in the appendix, skin, and breast tissues of 2 patients who exhibited Long COVID symptoms 163 and 426 days after symptom onset. With multiplex immunohistochemistry, viral nucleocapsid protein was detected in all three tissues. The nucleocapsid protein was further observed to co-localize with macrophage marker CD68, suggesting that immune cells were direct targets of SARS-CoV-2. Additionally, using RNAscope, the presence of viral RNA was also detected

There was a significantly lower frequency of the haplotype DQA1*01:01-DQB1*05:01-DRB1*01:01 in the asymptomatic group compared to the background population (P = .007).
Significant alteration of reproductive function at the molecular level. Several dysregulated proteins identified.
Beyond an association, as established in many previous reports, evidence from Mendelian randomization that Covid can cause atrophy in specific brain regions.

SARS-CoV-2-immunoreactive neurons were detected in the dorsal medulla and in the substantia nigra of five COVID-19 subjects. Viral RNA was also detected by real-time RT-PCR. The results of this study support the neuroinvasive potential of SARS-CoV-2.

COVID-19 patients had reduced thymic function, which was inversely associated with the severity of the disease. Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) was expressed by thymic epithelium, and in particular by medullary thymic epithelial cells (TEC). SARS-CoV-2 can target TECs and downregulate critical genes and pathways associated with epithelial cell adhesion and survival.
Persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection in patients seemingly recovered from COVID-19.
How SARS-CoV-2 battles our immune system
Only 9% of people with persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection reported having Long COVID

Muscle biopsy in-depth assessment in people with Long Covid with exercise symptoms compared with 2 control groups shows microvascular abnormalities with reduced capillaries, immune cell dysregulation, distinct gene expression signature.

Long COVID manifests with T cell dysregulation, inflammation, and an uncoordinated adaptive immune response to SARS-CoV-2. Individuals with LC harbored increased frequencies of CD4+ T cells poised to migrate to inflamed tissues, and exhausted SARS-CoV-2-specific CD8+ T cells. They also harbored significantly higher levels of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies, and in contrast to non-LC individuals, exhibited a mis-coordination between their SARS-CoV-2-specific T and B cell responses.

Blockage of TLR4 renders mice resistant to Spike-induced cognitive dysfunction. TLR4-2604G>A GG genotype (rs10759931) was related to poor cognitive outcomes in COVID-19 patients.
Class switch toward non-inflammatory, spike-specific IgG4 antibodies after repeated SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

To varying degrees, viral RNA is present in extrapulmonary tissues from all subjects. The majority of the 180 viral variants identified within subjects are unique to individual tissue samples.

Detailed evaluation of the lung immune compartment revealed that dysregulated respiratory CD8+ T cell responses were associated with the impaired lung function after acute COVID-19. Single-cell transcriptomic analysis identified the potential pathogenic subsets of respiratory CD8+ T cells contributing to persistent tissue conditions after COVID-19.

Using conventional immunohistochemistry, we detected SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein in the colon, appendix, ileum, haemorrhoid, liver, gallbladder and lymph nodes from 5 patients who recovered from COVID-19, 9-180 days after testing negative for SARS-CoV-2.
In pregnant women who tested positive for SARS-CoV-2, normalised fetal lung volume was significantly reduced compared with age-adjusted reference values.

Of the 109 patients, 29 (27%) experienced reactivation, and seven (24%) of these were symptomatic. The mean period for the real-time PCR tests for SARS-CoV-2 from negative to positive results was 17 days. Compared with patients without reactivation, those with reactivation were significantly younger and more likely to have a lymphocyte count of <1500/ŒºL (odds ratio [OR]: 0.34, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.12‚Äì0.94) and two or fewer symptoms (OR: 0.20, 95% CI: 0.07‚Äì0.55) during the initial episode.
Electrostatic interactions are a major contributing factor for increased Omicron transmissibility relative to other variants.
One year after infection, over 25% of people had lung diffusion issues.

Severe COVID-19 is marked by activated, highly cytotoxic CD16+ T cells. Immune-complex-mediated degranulation of CD16+ T cells causes endothelial cell injury. C3a-rich environment in severe COVID-19 promotes differentiation of CD16+ T cells. Activated CD16+ T cells and complement proteins are associated with fatal outcome

Deaths reported within 28 days of testing positive were 61% (95% confidence interval: 56% to 65%) lower in suspected COVID-19 reinfection than primary infection cases. In the unvaccinated cohort, reinfections were associated with 49% (37% to 58%) lower odds of hospital admission in cases aged 50 to 65 years in the population not identified at risk of complication for COVID-19, and 34% (17% to 48%) in those at risk.
SARS-CoV-2 invades cognitive centers of the brain and induces Alzheimer‚Äôs-like neuropathology.

Omicron variant of SARS-CoV-2 exhibits an increased resilience to the antiviral type I interferon response. IFN induction by Omicron is low and comparable to the wt, whereas Delta showed an increased IFN induction. However, Omicron exceeded both the wt and the Delta strain with respect to the ability to withstand the antiviral state imposed by IFN-alpha.

A low count of CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes is a hallmark laboratory finding in the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Using flow cytometry, significantly higher CD95 (Fas) and PD-1 expression on both CD4+ T and CD8+ T cells were observed in 42 COVID-19 patients when compared to controls. Higher CD95 expression in CD4+ cells correlated with lower CD4+ counts. A higher expression of CD95 in CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes correlated with a lower percentage of naive events. This suggests a shift to antigen-activated T cells, expressing molecules increasing their propensity to apoptosis and exhaustion during COVID-19 infection.

Not only are COVID-19 cases who got 2 vaccine doses reporting much less Long COVID symptoms than unvaccinated - they're reporting no more than uninfected people - suggesting vaccination brings these symptoms back to baseline.
Significant proportion of severe COVID19 patients actually developed auto-antibodies against interferon type I.
80% of peripheral T cells die during SARS Cov 2 infection, with proliferation of 20% of the CD8 T cell pool.
Significant posterior ocular structural & vascular alterations in patients with severe COVID infections.
üêÅCovid infects the central nervous system in mouse models. Inflammation was consistently observed, with death of endothelial, microglial and immune cells but without their apparent infection.

Alterations in brain functioning, especially in regions associated with cognition, can result from infection with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and are predicted to result in various psychiatric diseases.

The viral protein encoded by open reading frame 8 (ORF8) of SARS-CoV-2, which shares the least homology with SARS-CoV among all viral proteins, directly interacts with MHC-Œô molecules and mediates their down-regulation.

The effects of adaptive immunity deficiency in patients treated with B cell-depleting agents should be taken into account for the proper selection and interpretation of SARS-CoV-2 diagnostics and to guide appropriate therapeutic approaches and protective measures.

Wastewater based surveillance is a sensitive tool to monitor SARS-CoV-2 circulation levels and VOCs in larger regions. Differences in excretion levels of various SARS-CoV-2 variants should however be taken into account when using wastewater surveillance to monitor SARS-CoV-2 circulation levels in the population.

ORF3c suppresses RIG-I- and MDA5-mediated immune activation and interacts with the signaling adaptor MAVS. In line with this, ORF3c inhibits IFN-Œ≤ induction.
Critical SARS-CoV-2 infection was characterised by an increase in activated and cytotoxic CD4+ (CTL) cells of a T follicular helper (TFH) or effector memory re-expressing CD45RA (TEMRA) phenotype.
Out of 48 children the presence of SARS-CoV-2 was detected in at least one specimen in 25% (20% in palatine tonsils and 16.27% in adenoids, 10.41% of nasal cytobrush, and 6.25% of nasal wash).

Covid-19 infection was significantly associated with increased risks in early and late periods for anosmia and dysgeusia (hazard ratio 4.59 (95% confidence interval 3.63 to 5.80), risk difference 19.6 (95% confidence interval 16.9 to 22.4) in early period; 2.96 (2.29 to 3.82), 11.0 (8.5 to 13.6) in late period), cognitive impairment (1.85 (1.58 to 2.17), 12.8, (9.6 to 16.1); 1.69 (1.45 to 1.96), 13.3 (9.4 to 17.3)), dyspnoea (1.79 (1.68 to 1.90), 85.7 (76.9 to 94.5); 1.30 (1.22 to 1.38), 35.4 (26.3 to 44.6)), weakness (1.78 (1.69 to 1.88), 108.5, 98.4 to 118.6; 1.30 (1.22 to 1.37), 50.2 (39.4 to 61.1)), and palpitations (1.49 (1.35 to 1.64), 22.1 (16.8 to 27.4); 1.16 (1.05 to 1.27), 8.3 (2.4 to 14.1)) and with significant but lower excess risk for streptococcal tonsillitis and dizziness.

VEGF-A-triggered sensory neuron firing was blocked by spike protein and NRP-1 inhibitor EG00229. Pronociceptive behaviors of VEGF-A were similarly blocked through suppression of spontaneous spinal synaptic activity and reduction of electrogenic currents in sensory neurons.

Both early and late apoptotic cells in B and T lymphocytes were increased in all patients with COVID-19 (p‚Äâ<‚Äâ.05). Early apoptotic (EA) B and T lymphocytes were also higher in severe cases compared to mild cases (p‚Äâ=‚Äâ.026). There was no significant difference between lymphopenia and apoptosis in patients with COVID-19. However, patients with lymphopenia (n‚Äâ=‚Äâ14) and severe COVID-19 (p‚Äâ=‚Äâ.013) had increased EA T lymphocytes. This study's results show that B and T lymphocytes' apoptosis increases in patients with COVID-19. In addition, enhanced T lymphocyte apoptosis is associated with disease severity in lymphopenic patients with COVID-19.

Beyond the first 30 days of infection, people with COVID-19 exhibited increased risks and 1-year burdens of incident gastrointestinal disorders spanning several disease categories including motility disorders, acid related disorders (dyspepsia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, peptic ulcer disease), functional intestinal disorders, acute pancreatitis, hepatic and biliary disease. The risks were evident in people who were not hospitalized during the acute phase of COVID-19 and increased in a graded fashion across the severity spectrum of the acute phase of COVID-19 (non-hospitalized, hospitalized, and admitted to intensive care).

The results of 94,812 SARS-CoV-2 PCR tests collected longitudinally from >3,000 players, staff, and affiliates of the NBA over the course of the pandemic were analysed. Relative to first infections, second infections usually featured a lower peak viral concentration and faster clearance time, especially in individuals who received a vaccine dose between their first and second infection. Furthermore, a person‚Äôs relative (rank-order) viral clearance time, compared to others infected with the same variant, was similar across first and second infections; that is, individuals who had a relatively fast clearance time in their first infection tended to also have a relatively fast clearance time in their second infection.

Lung tissue sampling (needle biopsy), within ~2 hours of death, in 42 mechanically ventilated decedents during the Beta and Delta waves. Lung biopsy cores underwent viral culture, histopathological analysis, electron microscopy, transcriptomic profiling, immunohistochemistry and cell-based flow cytometry of deconstructed tissue. 38% (16/42) of patients had culturable virus in the lung (persisting for up to 4 weeks after symptom onset).

Characterized were immune cell and cytokine responses in 58 COVID-19 patients admitted to the hospital and 40 healthy controls of different age ranges. When the age range analysis was carried out, the immunological response to the infection was found to differ with age, being especially affected in the group of 30‚Äì39 years. In this age range, an increased exhausted T cell response and a decrease of na√Øve T helper lymphocytes was found in patients, as well as a reduced concentration of the pro-inflammatory TNF, IL-1Œ≤ and IL-8 cytokines.
PEG-specific antibodies can be induced or boosted by mRNA vaccination

The highest prevalence of SARS-CoV-2-positive tears using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction was found to be 7.5%. However, the highest prevalence of ocular conjunctivitis associated with SARS-CoV-2 was 32%. Thus, SARS-CoV-2 can evidently infect the eye, as revealed in the conjunctival secretions of COVID-19 patients.

Of 1323 randomized trial participants, 1125 consented for long-term follow up, and 95.1% completed >9 months of follow up. The median age was 45 years (IQR, 37 to 54), and 56% were female (7% pregnant). The median BMI was 30 kg/m2 (IQR, 27 to 34). Overall, 8.4% reported a medical provider diagnosed them with Long COVID; cumulative incidence: 6.3% with metformin and 10.6% with matched placebo. The hazard ratio (HR) for metformin preventing Long COVID was 0.58 (95%CI, 0.38 to 0.88; P=0¬∑009) versus placebo. The metformin effect was consistent across subgroups, including viral variants. When metformin was started within <4 days of symptom onset, the HR for Long COVID was 0.37 (95%CI, 0.15 to 0.95).  No statistical difference in Long COVID occurred in those randomized to either ivermectin (HR=0.99; 95%CI, 0.59 to 1.64) or fluvoxamine (HR=1.36; 95%CI, 0.78 to 2.34).
New analysis of 40 studies of pediatric Covid survivors, based on 12,424 individuals under 18, showed that the prevalence of any long COVID was 23.36%.

Spike protein can directly produce cellular damage and electrophysiological dysfunction, and this may confer the intrinsic, mechanistic susceptibility for increased risk of SCD(SUDDEN CARDIAC DEATH) observed in patients with COVID-19.

The main SARS-CoV-2 protease Nsp5 cleaves the TDP-43 protein into a cytotoxic form in human neural cells. SARS-CoV-2 infection results in multilineage neural cell dysregulation, decreased new neuron generation, and a reduction in overall brain size in patients, even those with mild respiratory COVID-19.

Despite negative SARS CoV-2 nasal PCRs from all newborns, viral RNAs and Spike protein were detected in the stool of 11 out of 14 newborns as early as the first day of life and increased over time in 6. Stool homogenates from all 14 newborns elicited elevated inflammatory IL-6 and IFN-Œ≥ from macrophages. Most newborns were clinically well except for one death from gestational autoimmune liver disease and another who developed necrotizing enterocolitis.

Evidence for persistent tissue-specific immunity to SARS-CoV-2 in the upper respiratory tract of children after infection. Pharyngeal tissues from COVID-19-convalescent children showed persistent expansion of germinal center and antiviral lymphocyte populations associated with interferon (IFN)-Œ≥-type responses, particularly in the adenoids, and viral RNA in both tissues.

Of 194,191 adults with COVID-19 infection, 6.3% were hospitalized, 3.1% experienced a deterioration event, and 2.8% died within 90 days. Dose‚Äíresponse effects were strong; for example, patients in the some activity category had higher odds of hospitalization (OR=1.43; 95% CI=1.26, 1.63), deterioration (OR=1.83; 95% CI=1.49, 2.25), and death (OR=1.92; 95% CI=1.48, 2.49) than those in the always active category. Results were generally consistent across sex, race and ethnicity, age, and BMI categories and for patients with cardiovascular disease or hypertension.

In recovered COVID-19 patients, the cell-bound component of mucosal immunity reveals lympho- and eosinopenia. The neutrophils population shows cytodestruction, increased apoptosis, and decreased functional and metabolic activity of the cell.
People who live at high altitudes were significantly more likely to get #LongCovid (72%, vs 29% in people living at low altitudes).

Prior to the widespread implementation of the COVID-19 vaccine, the incidence of newly diagnosed erectile dysfunction is higher in men with prior COVID-19 infection compared to age-matched controls. Prior COVID-19 infection was associated with a 27% increased likelihood of developing new-onset erectile dysfunction when compared to those without prior infection. 42,406 men experienced a COVID-19 infection between January 2020 and January 2021 of which 601 (1.42%) developed new onset erectile dysfunction within 6.5 months follow up. On multivariable analysis while controlling for diabetes, cardiovascular disease, smoking, obesity, hypogonadism, thromboembolism, and malignancy, prior COVID-19 infection was associated with increased risk of new onset erectile dysfunction (HR 1.27; 95% CI 1.1‚Äì1.5; P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.002).

183 studies were included, reporting data from 64,876 patients with COVID-19 worldwide. The overall prevalence of taste disorders was 38% (95% CI = 22% to 56%, I2 = 98%). Taste disorders were associated with a positive COVID-19 test (odds ratio [OR] = 7.54, 95% CI = 5.24 to 10.86, I2 = 93%, P < 0.00001), showing high certainty of evidence. Hypogeusia, dysgeusia, and ageusia were also evaluated by a meta-analysis, and the pooled prevalence was 34% for hypogeusia, 33% for dysgeusia, and 26% for ageusia. Xerostomia was a new feature of this update, and the pooled data demonstrated a prevalence of 43% (95% CI = 36% to 50%, I2 = 71%) in patients with COVID-19. Regarding oral mucosal lesions, the most common clinical pattern was aphthous like, followed by herpes-like lesions, candidiasis, glossitis/depapillation/geographic tongue, parotitis, and angular cheilitis. Oral lesions were more frequent in the tongue, lips, and palate, presenting miscellaneous clinical aspects that are more likely to represent coinfections.

Rapid Extracellular Antigen Profiling to characterize self- and viral-directed humoral responses after SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination in 145 healthy individuals, 38 patients with autoimmune diseases, and 8 patients with mRNA vaccine-associated myocarditis confirms that most individuals generated robust virus-specific antibody responses post vaccination, but that the quality of this response is impaired in autoimmune patients on certain modes of immunosuppression. Autoantibody dynamics are remarkably stable in all vaccinated patients compared to COVID-19 patients that exhibit an increased prevalence of new autoantibody reactivities. Patients with vaccine-associated myocarditis do not have increased autoantibody reactivities relative to controls.

Volumes of brainstem regions for 10 ME/CFS (CCC or ICC criteria), 8 long COVID (WHO Delphi consensus), and 10 healthy control (HC) subjects were compared on 3D, T1-weighted MRI images acquired using sub-millimeter isotropic resolution using an ultra-high field strength of 7 Tesla. Group comparisons with HC detected significantly larger volumes in ME/CFS for pons (p = 0.004) and whole brainstem (p = 0.01), and in long COVID for pons (p = 0.003), superior cerebellar peduncle (p = 0.009), and whole brainstem (p = 0.005). No significant differences were found between ME/CFS and long COVID volumes. In ME/CFS, we detected positive correlations between the pons and whole brainstem volumes with ‚Äúpain‚Äù and negative correlations between the midbrain and whole brainstem volumes with ‚Äúbreathing difficulty.‚Äù In long COVID patients a strong negative relationship was detected between midbrain volume and ‚Äúbreathing difficulty.‚Äù

Long COVID is a multisystemic illness encompassing ME/CFS, dysautonomia, impacts on multiple organ systems, and vascular and clotting abnormalities. On the basis of more than 2 years of research on long COVID and decades of research on conditions such as ME/CFS, a significant proportion of individuals with long COVID may have lifelong disabilities if no action is taken. Diagnostic and treatment options are currently insufficient, and many clinical trials are urgently needed to rigorously test treatments that address hypothesized underlying biological mechanisms, including viral persistence, neuroinflammation, excessive blood clotting and autoimmunity.

1 year after Covid in 301 participants 25% of the participants had impaired pulmonary function which translates in 11%, 22%, and 48% of the participants with mild, moderate and severe/critical COVID-19. (no controls)

Possible induction of protein aggregation by the SARS-CoV-2 3CL protease (3CLpro) possibly relevant in neuropathology, such as aggregation of tau, alpha-synuclein and TPD-43. High-throughput autoantibody discovery technique known as rapid extracellular antigen profiling was used to screen a cohort of 194 individuals infected with SARS-CoV-2, comprising 172 patients with COVID-19 and 22 healthcare workers with mild disease or asymptomatic infection, for autoantibodies against 2,770 extracellular and secreted proteins (members of the exoproteome). This review focuses on the emerging literature supporting the role(s) that viral persistence or reactivation of viruses may play in post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 infection (PASC). Infected animals exhibited highly scattered data distributions compared to their corresponding controls indicating the heterogeneity of the CSF proteome change and the host response to the viral infection. Dysregulated CSF proteins were preferentially enriched in functional pathways associated with progressive neurodegenerative disorders, hemostasis, and innate immune responses that could influence neuroinflammatory responses following COVID-19. Mapping these dysregulated proteins to the Human Brain Protein Atlas found that they tended to be enriched in brain regions that exhibit more frequent injury following COVID-19. Pharmacological or genetic downregulation of ASM protects against infection. The neutralization or degradation of ceramides on the cell surface also protects against infection. The addition of exogenous ceramide after the downregulation of ASM by pharmacological inhibition restores infection with SARS-CoV-2. Thus, ceramide on the cell surface is necessary for infection with SARS-CoV-2. The ASM/ceramide system may be important not only for virus entry into the cell but also for the release of cytokines such as IL-6. Antidepressants reduce the level of proinflammatory cytokines in preclinical studies and patients with major depressive disorder. Importantly, reduced IL-6 levels were also found in COVID-19 patients treated with the FIASMA hydroxyzine. The ASM/ceramide system can help to explain the typical risk factors for a lethal COVID-19 course since ceramide abundance is increased in advanced age, hypertension or obesity, and the increased rate of thromboembolic complications in the setting of COVID-19 can also be explained by the ASM/ceramide system. The ASM/ceramide system may also help to explain the negative effect of chloroquine in the therapy of patients with COVID-19.

SARS-CoV-2-specific T cell responses waned significantly in 75% of convalescent individuals during the follow-up.
Ocular fluids from SARS-CoV-2-infected patients may contain infectious virus, and hence may be a potential source of infection.

Compared with COVID-19-recovered and uninfected controls, respectively, subjects with long COVID were more likely to show thickening and hyperechogenic vagus nerve in neck ultrasounds (mean ¬± SD left vagus nerve cross-sectional area: 2.4 ¬± 0.97mm2 vs. 2 ¬± 0.52mm2 vs. 1.9 ¬± 0.73 mm2, p=0.080), flattened diaphragmatic curve (47% vs 6% vs 14%, p=0.007), reduced esophageal peristalsis (34% vs 0% vs 21%, p=0.020), gastroesophageal reflux (34% vs 19% vs 7%, p=0.130), hiatal hernia (25% vs 0% vs 7%, p=0.050) and reduced maximal inspiratory pressure in functional respiratory tests (62% vs. 6% vs. 17%, p ‚â§0.001).
Improvement of immune dysregulation and health-related quality of life in individuals with long COVID at 24-months following SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Brain blood clots in small study were full of amyloids. Harmful amyloids are various misfolded proteins with certain chemical & structural characteristics that also make them tough & prone to tangle together. Prions are also among amyloids.
The risk of an arterial thrombotic event, e.g. heart attack or stroke, on day zero of COVID infection was; 73x higher for vaccinated people, and 255x higher for unvaccinated.

SARS-CoV-2 infection can inhibit the growth and spread of certain solid tumors, including colon and kidney cancers. The key mechanism involves the SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (N) protein, which can interact with a protein called YBX1.
Having a prior Post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC) increases the chances of having more PASC in subsequent infections.
Maternal COVID-19 infection is associated with offspring neurodevelopmental disorders

Long COVID can come with neuroinvasiveness, neurotropism and neurovirulence; persistent systemic inflammation and cytokine storm; prolonged neuroinflammation; blood-brain barrier disruption; generation of autoantibodies; microvasculitis; prolonged endothelial dysfunction, platelet activation, and enhanced thrombin generation; silent hypoxia and associated issues; dysregulated levels of neurotransmitters like serotonin and dopamine; amyloid aggregation; tau phosphorylation; protein misfolding; neuronal death; changes in grey matter volume; prolonged immunological dysfunction; dysregulation of the cholinergic system; chronic alteration of the extended autonomic system including neuroendocrine and neuroimmune systems; altered gut-brain axis functioning; and post-traumatic stress disorder, increased amygdala and hippocampal activity.

Hepatitis is a known complication of multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children following COVID-19, and SARS-CoV-2 has been linked to increased susceptibility to infection post-COVID-19, which may suggest complex causal pathways including a possible interaction with adeno-associated virus 2 (AAV-2) infection/reactivation in hosts that are genetically susceptible or sensitised to infection. Based on the Bradford Hill criteria and modelling, human adenovirus (HAdv) alone is unlikely to be the cause of the recent increase in hepatitis in children. The causal link between SARS-CoV-2, and to a lesser degree AAV-2, appears substantially stronger but remains unproven.
Findings suggest the pancreatic adenocarcinoma as the most possible malignancy occurring after sever infection with SARS-CoV family.

Using single-cell genomics it is shown that T cells in myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME) cases are epigenetically predisposed toward terminal exhaustion and that exhaustion markers are upregulated following exercise challenge.

SARS-CoV-2 spike protein persists in the skull-meninges-brain axis in COVID-19 patients. Spike protein is sufficient to induce brain pathological and behavioral changes in mice. Spike protein enhances brain vulnerability and exacerbates neurological damage in mice. mRNA vaccines reduce, but do not eliminate, the spike burden
This study identifies a region in the SARS-CoV-2 S2 spike protein with sequence homology to bacterial super-antigens (termed P3).
Risk of long COVID reaches 37% after three infections, according to INSPQ. The risk of long COVID is estimated at: 13% after infection; 23% during a second infection; 37% during a third infection.
Receptors like ACE2 and neuropilin-1 allow the virus to enter cells. Differences in these receptors due to genetics, age can impact infection risk

Long COVID patients reported persistent cognitive symptoms such as memory problems and brain fog, with higher levels of fatigue and reduced quality of life compared to controls. Despite subjective cognitive complaints, cognitive tests did not reveal significant differences between groups, except for the TMT-A (p‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.05). MRI analysis revealed decreased volume in the cerebellum (p‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.03), lingual gyrus (p‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.04), and inferior parietal regions (p‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.03), and reduced cortical thickness in several areas, including the left and right postcentral gyri (p‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.02, p‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.03) and precuneus (p‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.01, p‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.02).

Ivermectin doesn't kill the virus. It doesn't even kill the adult parasite it targets. It only paralyzes the larvae so its a protracted treatment. And because its a neurologic, IVM can cause brain damage. In as little as 15mg dose, IVM can cause stroke-like symptoms.

SARS-CoV-2 causes hyperglycemia directly, regardless of corticoid use, stress due to hospitalization, body weight and diabetes. SARS-CoV-2 infection was independently associated with hyperglycemia, regardless of diabetic history and beta cell function. SARS-CoV-2 infects and replicates in hepatocytes. Infected hepatocytes increase glucose production and this is associated with induction of phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase activity (a rate-limiting enzyme for hepatic glucose production through gluconeogenesis).

The 31 studies included 15,000 children, and researchers recorded more than 20 persistent symptoms. 16.2% (95% confidence interval [CI], 8.5% to 28.6%) of the pediatric participants experienced 1 or more persistent symptoms at least 3 months post COVID-19. Symptoms included fatigue, depression, sleep disturbance, cough, throat pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms. The three most common persistent symptoms seen in the studies were sore throat with a pooled estimate of 14.8% (95% CI, 4.8% to 37.5%); persistent fever, with an estimate of 10.9 (95% CI, 2.4% to 38.2%); and sleep disturbance, with an estimate of 10.3% (95% CI, 4.9% to 20.4%).

Individuals who had been infected with COVID-19 and had symptoms lasting ‚â• 12 weeks showed lower accuracy on cognitive tasks compared to uninfected individuals. Those with shorter symptom duration (<12 weeks) or who had recovered to their own satisfaction did not show significant deficits compared to uninfected groups. The deficit in accuracy for those with ‚â•12 weeks of symptoms was not trivial: it's comparable to the cognitive effect of being hospitalized during COVID, or having moderate psychological distress, or being ~10 years older in age. Reaction time (speed) was not significantly affected overall. In longitudinal follow-up (‚âà 9-month follow-up after initial testing), those with long symptom duration or ongoing symptoms generally showed little recovery in cognitive accuracy deficits. The deficits persisted at almost two years after infection in some individuals. Among participants who reported that they had recovered / felt back to normal after their COVID illness, no detectable deficits in cognitive accuracy were observed compared to uninfected people.

The prevalence of hospitalization tended to be higher during the first infection than the second infection. But transfer to the ICU tended to be lower during the first infection (0.71%, 7/984) than the second infection (1.52%, 15/984). No clear evidence of different clinical patterns between primary and second infection were found.

Long COVID with cognitive impairment is associated with abnormal cortical thickening in cognition-related brain areas and elevated inflammatory markers (IL-10, IFNŒ≥, sTREM2), suggesting neuroinflammation-driven brain changes that may underpin cognitive symptoms. Long COVID patients had lower MoCA scores than both control groups (mean 25.9 vs 27.2‚Äì28.0). Elevated IL-10, IFNŒ≥, and sTREM2 in long-COVID with cognitive impairment, no consistent increases in classical pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNFŒ±). sTREM2 increase suggests microglial activation and neuronal injury, similar to early Alzheimer‚Äôs disease.

There is evidence that viral RNA may persist in certain tissues for a long time after COVID-19 infection (up to nearly two years in some cases). This is associated with ongoing immune activation (particularly T cells) in various body regions. T cell activation doesn‚Äôt only occur in people with Long COVID symptoms. Certain tissues (gut wall, spinal cord) show stronger association with symptoms. That suggests some, but not all, of the immune activation may contribute to symptom persistence. The study investigated long-term tissue-level immune activation and viral persistence in people after SARS-CoV-2 infection, including in those with Long COVID symptoms. It uses imaging and tissue biopsies to look for evidence that virus or immune activation might linger long after acute infection. 24 people who had had COVID-19, imaged at times ranging 27 to 910 days after acute infection. Some had Long COVID symptoms, some didn‚Äôt. PET imaging using a tracer called [^18F]F-AraG, which specifically marks activated T lymphocytes. That allows anatomical quantification of T cell activation in various tissues. For a subset of Long COVID participants, colorectal tissue biopsies (rectosigmoid) were examined for presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA via in situ hybridization, and via immunohistochemistry. Blood plasma protein profiling showed that people with more Long COVID symptoms (>5) and higher tissue uptake had elevated markers of immune activation/inflammation. In biopsied colorectal (rectosigmoid) tissue from a subset of Long COVID participants, SARS-CoV-2 RNA (spike gene) was detected in lamina propria cells. The period after infection ranged from ~158 to ~676 days. In spinal cord and gut wall in particular, the degree of T cell activation was associated with presence of Long COVID symptoms. Elevated activation in a variety of tissues, even long after infection (up to ~2.5 years). T cell activation (measured by PET tracer uptake) was higher in the post-acute COVID group compared to controls in many anatomical sites: brainstem, spinal cord, gut wall, bone marrow, hilar lymphoid tissue, cardiopulmonary tissue, nasopharyngeal tissue, etc.

Sample: 13 COVID-positive cases and 27 control participants; mean age ~24 years, age range 13-25. All participants had baseline (pre-COVID) MRI (structural + resting-state functional MRI) and cognitive testing, and then follow-up after some got infected. Cognitive test used: spatial working memory from the CANTAB battery. Analyses: Volumetric_Œî: change in cortical/subcortical volumes pre‚Üípost COVID vs controls. Eigenvector Centrality_Œî (ECŒî): change in centrality in various brain regions (a measure from functional connectivity / network analysis) pre‚Üípost COVID vs controls. Decline in volume of the left hippocampus in COVID-positive group vs controls (Volumetric_Œî significantly different; p ‚âà 0.041). In particular, reduced EC_Œî in the left amygdala was observed in the COVID+ group. COVID+ participants showed reduced performance in spatial working memory compared to controls post-infection. Importantly, the reduction in connectivity (EC_Œî) in the left amygdala mediated the relationship between having had COVID-19 and poorer spatial working memory. These effects were observed even though infections were mild and in young people; suggesting that even mild COVID-19 may lead to lasting structural/functional brain changes and modest cognitive changes.

SARS-CoV-2 RNA (including antisense strand, indicating active replication) was detected in CD4‚Å∫ T cells that had been exposed ex vivo. Also, in samples from COVID-19 patients, CD4‚Å∫ T cells (but not CD8‚Å∫ T cells) from peripheral blood carried viral RNA; similarly, in bronchoalveolar lavage (lung fluid) of severe patients, a small percentage of CD4‚Å∫ T cells had SARS-CoV-2 RNA. Molecular modeling (docking + molecular dynamics simulations) suggested that the Spike RBD of SARS-CoV-2 can bind to the N-terminal domain (NTD) of CD4, in a region that overlaps the ACE2 binding domain. The interaction was confirmed by co-immunoprecipitation: Spike protein and CD4 physically bind in assays. Infection of CD4‚Å∫ T cells altered their function: some effects on gene expression (immune response genes) and possibly exhaustion or changes that could affect helper T cell function. (E.g. suppression of cytokine production, modulation of immune activation.). Proportion of CD4‚Å∫ T cells infected in vivo appears small; it‚Äôs not yet clear how much direct infection contributes vs other causes of T cell depletion or dysfunction.

Discuss findings from autopsy, biopsy, surgical specimens, and studies of children with acute infection, multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C), long COVID, etc. Children can have SARS-CoV-2 RNA or antigens remaining in various tissues (not only in the respiratory tract) for weeks to months after infection. This occurs independent of disease severity, meaning even kids with mild illness sometimes show evidence of persistence. There are reports of systemic spread in children (i.e., presence in organs/tissues beyond the nose/throat) in some autopsy / biopsy cases.

Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from Long COVID patients show elevated expression and activity of indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase-2 (IDO2) (vs infected non-Long COVID and controls). In brain tissue (from the two autopsy cases), IDO2 is also expressed long after infection. Long COVID PBMCs show reduced mitochondrial function (lower respiration / spare capacity). Lower intracellular amino acids, and lower levels of metabolites of the Krebs (TCA) cycle. Increased signs of autophagy, and signs of apoptosis in some cases. The degradation products of tryptophan (kynurenine metabolites) are altered: specific patterns correlate with severity/symptomology. The enzyme IDO2 seems to be a driver of these changes. Ex vivo, using an AHR (aryl hydrocarbon receptor) antagonist reduces IDO2 expression and reduces autophagy in PBMCs. Brain tissue sample is very limited (only two Long COVID autopsy cases), so generalizability for brain findings is uncertain.

After mRNA vaccination, germinal centre (GC) B cells specific to SARS-CoV-2 spike persist for many months. The lymph node (LN) aspirates showed robust spike-specific GC activity even weeks after vaccination. This supports durable maturation of the antibody response. Antibodies elicited by vaccination do neutralize multiple variants, but (unsurprisingly) neutralization is lower for more antigenically divergent variants. Prior infection + vaccination (‚Äúhybrid‚Äù immunity) generally gives broader and stronger neutralization compared to vaccination alone. Evidence of ‚Äúimmune imprinting‚Äù (sometimes called ‚Äúoriginal antigenic sin‚Äù in other viral systems) was observed.

Having had a prior Omicron infection (BA.1/BA.2) was associated with higher risk of reinfection with Omicron (likely BA.5) during this period, especially in the 9‚Äì29 days after the first Omicron infection. The hazard ratio for reinfection was very high in that early window. Those who got reinfected had lower neutralizing antibody titres (for both ancestral strain and Omicron BA.1), and lower anti-RBD IgG and IgA antibodies after their initial Omicron infection, compared to those who did not get reinfected. Time since last vaccine dose, age, sex, frailty, and number of facility outbreaks were not significantly associated with reinfection risk in the group already with prior Omicron infection. Some different vaccine brand combinations (mRNA-1273 vs BNT162b2) showed small signals of different risk, but overall hybrid immunity in this older cohort was quite heterogeneous. The study investigated 750 older adults (residents of long-term care and retirement homes) who were highly vaccinated (four doses of monovalent mRNA vaccine) to see how well hybrid immunity (vaccine + infection) protects against reinfection, particularly with Omicron subvariants. In a subset of 318 of these residents, immunologic assays were done (antibody levels, neutralization, T cell memory) in the three months before that observation period.

Researchers analyzed biopsies of fungiform papillae‚Äîthe taste structures on the tongue in 16 individuals with long-term taste loss compared to pre-pandemic and never-infected controls. Using microscopy, immunofluorescence, and RNA in situ hybridization, they found SARS-CoV-2 proteins (spike and nucleocapsid) in the epithelial layers and lamina propria of the papillae. In several cases, negative-strand RNA was also detected, indicating active viral replication in taste tissue up to 40 weeks after infection. The infected papillae showed disrupted taste bud architecture, with missing or misshapen buds and a loss of neurite fibers that normally connect to sensory nerves. Patients with partial recovery over time displayed regrowth of nerve fibers and restoration of papilla structure, while viral protein clearance appeared patchy across the tongue. These findings provide strong evidence that long-term taste dysfunction in COVID-19 is linked to local viral persistence and structural damage rather than solely systemic inflammation. The results underscore that some Long COVID symptoms may stem from direct viral reservoirs in sensory tissues, highlighting the importance of exploring antiviral and regenerative strategies for treatment.

Over two years, most of the 341 people who developed long COVID in a cohort of 548 COVID-19 survivors did not fully recover: only ~8% recovered in the first 24 months. Risk of developing long COVID was higher in females, those with lower education, and those who experienced symptoms like fatigue, headache, tachycardia, respiratory issues, or neurocognitive complaints during acute infection. Certain factors (ICU stay, smell/taste loss, cardiovascular problems) increased odds of recovery, while muscle pain, attention impairment, and breathing or heart rate problems reduced it. Long COVID is not uniform but clusters into subtypes: patients in the ‚Äúless complex‚Äù fatigue-dominated cluster had much better recovery odds than those with more symptoms.

Multiple studies reviewed by Proal et al. identify SARS-CoV-2 RNA or proteins in gut mucosa, skin, olfactory tissues, and other organs from months up to over a year post-infection‚Äîeven when PCR tests from the respiratory tract are negative. Immune system readouts in these patients often show signs of ongoing activation: broadened or elevated T cell responses, presence of viral protein in plasma or extracellular vesicles, sometimes immune exhaustion markers.

SARS-CoV-2 spike protein triggers infected cells (especially in lung tissue) to fuse into syncytia, which may worsen disease by damaging tissue structure and function. By screening over 3,000 already approved drugs, they found 83 compounds that block spike-driven cell fusion, many of which also reduce viral replication and protect cells in culture. Among these, niclosamide stood out as effective by dampening calcium oscillations and interfering with TMEM16F activity. TMEM16 (ion channel / scramblase) proteins play a central role in syncytium formation by facilitating exposure of phosphatidylserine on cell surfaces.

SARS-CoV-2 infection typically induces strong IgG1 and IgG3 antibody responses, which are good at neutralization, activating complement, and stimulating inflammation. However, in some severe COVID-19 cases, elevated levels of IgG4 have been observed‚Äîa subclass of antibodies known for reduced inflammatory activity and poor complement activation. Rubio-Casillas et al. propose that the virus may induce IgG4 synthesis as a strategy to reduce immune pressure and promote immune tolerance, perhaps allowing residual viral antigen or infection to persist.

Children who recover from SARS-CoV-2 infection generate strong and lasting immune responses focused on the viral Spike protein. These responses do not just disappear: over months, many maintain both antibodies and T cell reactivity. Crucially, the antibodies and T cells are not only specific to the infecting strain, but often cross-react with newer variants‚Äô spike proteins‚Äîthough with reduced strength for more divergent variants.

After SARS-CoV-2 infection, circulating immune cells (T, B, NK cells, monocytes) show altered gene expression that persists well into the post-acute period. Many genes involved in inflammation (especially NF-Œ∫B, AP-1, TNF pathways) are upregulated, including genes that are normally regulated in an anti-inflammatory direction under low-dose IL-2 therapy. These pro-inflammatory shifts are detectable for at least 2 months after symptom onset, and in some cases up to 3-4 months. The pattern is distinct from what is seen in influenza or sepsis, suggesting a COVID-specific immune perturbation.

Many individuals who recover from COVID-19 experience persistent neurological symptoms well beyond the acute phase, according to this survey study. Symptoms such as headaches, dizziness, memory or concentration difficulties (‚Äúbrain fog‚Äù), and sensory disturbances are common, and can persist for many months. The study finds that even those with initially mild COVID-19, or who are relatively young, report such long-term neurological sequelae, though risks are higher among those who had more severe acute illness.

In a largely triple-vaccinated adult population infected with the SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant in Western Australia, approximately 18% reported new or ongoing symptoms consistent with Long COVID three months after infection. Fatigue and problems with concentration were the most commonly reported symptoms in this study by the Western Australia Department of Health. Individuals at higher risk included women, middle-aged adults (50-69), those with pre-existing health conditions, people living in rural/remote areas, and those with fewer vaccine doses. Nearly one in five people who had been working or studying before their infection cut back or stopped these activities.

Severe SARS-CoV-2 infection leads to lasting epigenetic reprogramming in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs), detectable up to a year after acute illness. These changes include altered chromatin accessibility favoring inflammatory gene programs and increased myelopoiesis. The amplified epigenetic ‚Äúmemory‚Äù gets transmitted to downstream innate immune cells (e.g., monocytes), which display hyper-responsive inflammatory behavior even months later. early high levels of IL-6 during infection contribute to establishing this epigenetic memory, and blocking IL-6 signaling in a mouse model mitigates some of the persistent immune reprogramming. These findings suggest that long-term immune alterations after COVID-19 aren‚Äôt just in mature immune cells but are rooted at the stem/progenitor level.

In a group of patients evaluated on average 5.5 months after SARS-CoV-2 infection, researchers found biopsy-proven chronic myocarditis in the heart tissue, including persistent viral RNA (virus presence), ongoing inflammation, and elevated levels of anti-heart autoantibodies. Endomyocardial biopsies confirmed inflammation and viral persistence well beyond the acute phase, even in patients without prior cardiac disease.

In a predominantly Latino, low-education, farmworker population in California, nearly 62% of those who had had a SARS-CoV-2 infection (suspected or confirmed) reported at least one symptom persisting beyond 28 days‚Äîmeeting a standard operational definition of long COVID. These lingering symptoms (fatigue, dyspnea, smell/taste disturbance) were associated with markers of inflammation (higher CRP), higher BMI, and poorer mental & physical health metrics compared to non-infected or short-symptom individuals.

A prospective cohort study monitoring 136 SARS-CoV-2-infected individuals from within days of diagnosis found that those who later reported persistent symptoms at 4 months (i.e., PASC/Long COVID) had higher early viral loads in nasal swabs, more prolonged infectious virus shedding, and higher plasma nucleocapsid antigen during acute infection than those who fully recovered. Also, they mounted a delayed Spike IgG antibody response compared to non-PASC participants in the early days of illness. Cytokine/inflammatory markers during acute infection did not clearly distinguish future PASC from recovery, suggesting that it‚Äôs the viral burden and the ability to mount early humoral responses that may drive long COVID risk.

Investigators analyzed sudden, unexplained deaths during the COVID-19 era by performing post-mortem molecular testing of tissue to detect SARS-CoV-2 RNA. They found that in some cases classified as unexplained, viral RNA was detectable, indicating that COVID-19 might have contributed to mortality in cases where it was not clinically identified.

The SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (N) protein suppresses apoptosis (cell death) by stabilizing the host anti-apoptotic protein MCL-1, via interaction with USP15 that removes K63-linked ubiquitin from MCL-1. This leads to protection of infected cells from the mitochondrial pro-apoptotic protein Bak, allowing infected cells to survive longer and enabling better viral replication. The effect is demonstrated in multiple cell types, lung organoids, and in mouse models. This anti-apoptotic mechanism isn‚Äôt unique to SARS-CoV-2: N protein expression enhances replication of other viral pathogens (IAV, DENV, ZIKV) in co-infection settings, while pharmacologic inhibition of MCL-1 diminishes this effect.

About five months after hospitalisation for moderate to severe COVID-19, a majority (‚âà61%) of patients exhibit MRI evidence of abnormalities in at least two organs (lung, brain, kidney) compared to non-COVID controls (‚âà27%). The most notable findings include parenchymal lung damage, white matter lesions and regional brain volume loss, and kidney changes such as altered MRI T1 and impaired corticomedullary differentiation. Heart and liver imaging did not show substantially increased abnormalities in COVID versus control groups. Patients more likely to have multiorgan MRI abnormalities tended to be older, with more comorbidities, and had more severe acute disease (e.g., elevated CRP).

After the rollout of molnupiravir in 2022, SARS-CoV-2 genome sequence databases show distinct mutational signatures (notably elevated G‚ÜíA and C‚ÜíT transitions) in certain long phylogenetic branches. These mutational patterns are highly consistent with those seen in clinical cases treated with molnupiravir, especially in specific nucleotide sequence contexts. The study links these long branches to molnupiravir usage by geography, patient age groups, and through matching the mutation spectra of treated vs untreated viruses.

COVID-19 can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo, and balance problems (‚Äúaudiovestibular symptoms‚Äù) in some patients. This study shows that the inner ear‚Äôs hair cells and Schwann cells are biologically capable of SARS-CoV-2 infection: they express the receptor ACE2 and proteases (TMPRSS2, FURIN), and in tissue explants, organoids, and OPC models the virus infects hair cells.

This autopsy study created specific PCR tests to track where COVID-19 mRNA vaccines go in the body and for how long after injection. In people who died of other causes, vaccine mRNA was routinely detectable for up to 30 days in several tissues. In a subset, myocardial tissue also contained vaccine mRNA during that window; these samples more often showed healing injury and more macrophages than hearts without detectable vaccine mRNA.

Researchers analyzed autopsy samples from COVID-19 patients and used advanced imaging and RNA assays (RNAscope, including antisense strand detection) to locate viral RNA in coronary plaques. They found SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA, including replicative (antisense) strands, in macrophages within coronary plaques in all examined cases. Plaques with foam cell macrophages (i.e. cholesterol-loaded macrophages) were especially prone to infection. Blocking the entry cofactor NRP-1 reduces infection, suggesting one mechanistic pathway. Infected macrophages and ex vivo plaque tissues mount a strong inflammatory response with release of key cytokines implicated in plaque instability and cardiovascular events.

A previously healthy 62-year-old man developed rapidly progressive neurologic decline‚Äîdementia, movement abnormalities, myoclonus‚Äîconcurrent with COVID-19 infection, with CSF positivity for 14-3-3 protein and no alternative explanations found. Clinical, imaging, and lab findings fulfilled criteria for probable prion disease, though MRI and EEG results were nonspecific. He deteriorated quickly and died within weeks.

Two host proteases, TMPRSS2 and ADAM17, both cleave the ACE2 receptor, but only TMPRSS2‚Äôs action increases Spike-mediated viral entry in cell culture. TMPRSS2 cleaves ACE2 in a way that augments virus uptake, while ADAM17's cleavage results in shedding of soluble ACE2, which doesn‚Äôt facilitate entry.

In an immunocompromised individual with prolonged Omicron BA.1 infection, SARS-CoV-2 evolved into a novel sub-lineage (BA.1.23) over several weeks, accumulating key spike mutations associated with immune escape. This evolved variant was subsequently transmitted to at least three other patients, some of whom also developed persistent infection, demonstrating that evolution in one host can produce a transmissible, immune-evasive lineage. The study also documents minority viral variants (miSNVs) that later become fixed or appear in onward-transmitted cases, showing intrahost variation as a pool for adaptation. BA.1.23 exhibits substantially reduced neutralization by sera from boosted vaccination or previous BA.1 infection, more so than BA.1 itself.

Eighteen years after surviving SARS, many of the former patients still experience lasting health problems: persistent fatigue, reduced lung function, bone issues (osteoporosis, hip necrosis), and structural lung lesions on CT imaging. While emotional and mental health appear largely recovered, physical and social functioning lag behind that of matched controls. Functional measures, such as respiratory capacity and hip joint performance, remain impaired though somewhat improved compared to earlier follow-ups. At the molecular level, the SARS survivors show long-term abnormalities in metabolism (amino acids, lipids), increased activity of immune pathways (especially B cells, cytotoxic CD8+ T cells), and decreased function in antigen presentation by CD4+ T cells.

Infants infected with SARS-CoV-2 (Omicron or earlier variants) develop robust and long-lived antibody immunity, with (unlike in many adult studies) antibody levels showing no decay for nearly a year (‚âà300 days) after infection. Their immune reactions in nasal mucosa activate antiviral and interferon pathways early, while systemic inflammation is muted. These findings contrast with adult immune dynamics, where antibodies often wane more quickly and systemic cytokine responses are larger.

SARS-CoV-2 infection can disrupt the blood‚Äìbrain barrier (BBB). Mechanisms include inflammation, endothelial injury, and cytokine-driven permeability increases that allow viral particles, immune cells, and inflammatory molecules to cross into the brain.

A pilot study in Central India compared young athletes aged 20‚Äì30 who had recovered from COVID-19 with those never infected. The post-COVID group had significantly lower VO‚ÇÇ max and higher resting heart and respiratory rates, indicating reduced cardiorespiratory fitness despite clinical recovery.

In this study of symptomatic adults during the Omicron era, researchers found that SARS-CoV-2 viral loads typically peak 4‚Äì5 days after symptom onset, rather than at onset as observed early in the pandemic. As a result, rapid antigen tests are much less sensitive in the first two days of symptoms (30‚Äì60%) but reach over 80% sensitivity by day 4. In comparison, influenza A viral loads peaked earlier, on day 2, matching pre-pandemic expectations.

Three previously healthy adults with severe long COVID, suffering from disabling fatigue, cognitive impairment, and exercise intolerance for months after infection each received the casirivimab/imdevimab monoclonal antibody cocktail (against spike protein SARS-CoV-2), leading to rapid, complete remission of all symptoms within one week. The recovery was confirmed by family members and sustained for at least two years.

This cohort study of 248 hospitalized COVID-19 patients found that a subset developed autoantibodies, particularly anti-phospholipid antibodies (16.5%) and, less frequently, antinuclear antibodies (2%). Many of these antibodies persisted for months (e.g., 69% of IgM anti-Œ≤2-GPI remained positive), suggesting a durable autoimmune response triggered by SARS-CoV-2 infection. While most autoantibody-positive patients did not experience worse outcomes, IgG anticardiolipin positivity was associated with more severe clinical trajectories.

üß´Using human pancreatic tissue and cell models, researchers show that SARS-CoV-2 infects and replicates in both endocrine and exocrine pancreatic cells. In Œ≤ cells, infection correlates with fewer insulin secretory granules and blunted insulin release in response to glucose, while exocrine cell infection points to wider pancreatic involvement. Infectious virus was recoverable, confirming productive replication in the pancreas.

Severe COVID-19 patients often exhibit gut fungal dysbiosis, particularly overgrowth of Candida albicans. This is associated with elevated antifungal antibodies, systemic neutrophilia, and lasting transcriptional changes in granulocyte progenitors, indicating durable immune reprogramming. These immune changes persisted for up to a year after recovery, suggesting that gut fungi act as long-term drivers of systemic inflammation.üêÅIn mouse models, Candida colonization exacerbated lung inflammation during SARS-CoV-2 infection, while antifungal therapy or IL-6 receptor blockade/tocilizumab mitigated these effects. Patients treated with tocilizumab also showed reduced antifungal antibodies and immune reprogramming.

In a large cohort of U.S. Medicare patients aged 65+, early outpatient treatment for COVID-19 with nirmatrelvir-ritonavir (Paxlovid) was associated with a modest but statistically significant reduction in the risk of developing post-COVID-19 condition (Long COVID) symptoms at 4-12 weeks after infection. The untreated group had a ~14.5% incidence of PCC; treatment with nirmatrelvir lowered that to ~11.8%, for an absolute risk reduction of ~2.7%. Molnupiravir also showed some benefit but smaller, with an absolute risk reduction of ~0.8%. Overall, among 3‚ÄØ975‚ÄØ690 outpatients with COVID-19, 57% remained in the study after exclusion. Among them, 19.5% received nirmatrelvir and 2.6% received molnupiravir.

This methodological critique shows that mask trials/meta-analyses conflate infections occurring inside the study‚Äôs controlled setting with those acquired outside it, mathematically biasing effect estimates toward the null and yielding over-narrow confidence intervals. A simple correction using the fraction of outside infections (b) reveals that many ‚Äúno difference‚Äù conclusions are uninformative: a wide range of true effects could produce observed risk ratios near 1 when b is large. Re-examining key datasets (including Loeb 2022) and the Cochrane review under this framework, the authors argue that N95s likely provide substantially greater protection than surgical masks, and that accounting for source control and two-way masking magnifies benefits. This study shows that SARS-CoV can persistently replicate in human renal tubular epithelial cells, maintaining productive infection with limited cell damage.
